posts.name: saara sherazi
posts.cooked: Hiya! FTC team captain here looking to ask how feasible Swerve is in FTC . I transferred over from FRC , and was horrified to find that swerve modules would not work in FTC . I heard that they can be 3D printed as well. Can anyone with a 3D printing file share it? I’m making it an off season project for the kids. Thanks!

posts.name: Leo
posts.cooked:
Swerve isn’t really feasible in FTC . It’s benefits don’t really matter (grip/pushing power), and its drawbacks (size/complexity/# motors) matter a lot more.

Mecanum drive isn’t used in FRC because you can get pushed around easily/have less power, but this doesn’t matter in FTC because there is no defense. FTC is a lot more motor limited both in slots and power, so using 2 motors per wheel for swerve isn’t feasible because it leaves you with a lot less slots for subsystems.

Thats why mecanum is so popular in FTC , and why it’s probably the option you should be going with as a newish FTC team.

Though they rarely use it, there is an FTC team near me with both coaxial and differential swerve modules that they have made, I don’t know if they’ve ever used them on a competition robot, but I can find that out if people are interested.

posts.name: Sophia
posts.cooked:
There is an entire discord server dedicated to swerve in FTC , though I would not recommend it as it’s expensive and complicated.

Check out the Swerve Alliance Swerver community on Discord - hang out with 645 other members and enjoy free voice and text chat.

posts.name: saara sherazi
posts.cooked: yeah my team has a 3d printer so i think that could be super helpful! tysm!

posts.name: saara sherazi
posts.cooked: which team would that be? its also out of personal curiosity LOL

posts.name: saara sherazi
posts.cooked: honestly you’re probably right… my software kids look like i kicked their puppy every time i bring it up. i doubt we’re gonna use it competitively, since it isnt feasible this season and i’d rather order mechanum in that case. i think it’d make an interesting off-season project, though!

I understand the sentiment, mecanum are boring.  But, they just plain work for the game.  Most veteran FTC teams (ours included) have dabbled with swerve but in the end there never seems to be a competitive advantage to balance the extra cost and effort needed to make swerve work.  With Gobuilda’s new grippier rollers, mecanum is now more bulletproof than ever (for better or worse depending on your point of view).  Unless the GDC brings back floor obstacles I can’t see mecanum being dethroned.

If you want to give it a go start by checking out Kookybotz (team 16379) from 2023.  They had a very impressive two servo per wheel setup.  This is still the best swerve chassis we’ve seen on the field.  Having talked to them at our regional championship, the team felt it was a fun and challenging flex, but didn’t intend to duplicate it.  They dropped back to mecanum for last season.  I’ve never seen them here but they are usually active on Reddit.

If you’re looking for a design to play with, check out Terravoxel .  While this one’s just theoretical, they did publish their Onshape CAD which can help you jumpstart your own design.
The Tungsten Tigers have published theirs . They were also on Behind the Bot .

posts.name: wgorgen
posts.cooked:
One of the FTC teams in our club did swerve on their 2016-17 bot.

The module “forks” were 3D printed, but the rest of the module was actobotics parts. It used continuous rotation servos for steering.

I’m 90% sure that the design is posted on grabcad. I’ll have to ask my son. He still has the 5th module on his desk and it is still in working order (he hooks it up to a simple power supply and runs it every now and then).

posts.name: Ryan Harrelson
posts.cooked:
The FTC team that I coached back in 2018/2019 did run swerve drive for the SKYSTONE season. We used a slightly modified version of the design that team 9773 released the prior year. One of the students on the team had found 9773’s design and a few of our students got together and really wanted to try it. We made them a deal that if they could fund raise for the parts and get it up and running by the next season kickoff that they could use it during the following season. They took it on as their summer project and had it up and running by August so we went into the season with it.

Ironically SKYSTONE was probably better suited for swerve than most of the others I’ve seen. That year you had to travel diagonally from one corner of the field to the other to grab game pieces and place them. The bot was quick, moved really well and the few collisions it got into crossing the field it was the one that stayed on course.

Was it worth it? From a purely competition standpoint, I’d say no. It was expensive and time consuming to build and program. We also had some 3D printed parts (pulleys mainly) fail in our first competitions. Luckily the failures were on the Drive and not Azimuth so the robot was still operational. We didn’t get our game piece manipulator final design down until just before the State competition due to spending time working on Swerve.

Was it worth it from an educational standpoint and a “cool” factor, for that I’d say yes. Judges really liked it, and it always drew a lot of attention at competitions. The kids definitely had a lot of stories for judges about the pains of trying something new and learning through failures.

Overall from a competitive standpoint there just aren’t enough benefits over mecanum in FTC to warrant the extra work & cost, but for us the experience, I think, was worth it at the time.

soup:

only real question is, do the servos drain battery badly?

Far from the only important question, but no, compared to the power consumed by your DC motors, servos are consuming much less power.  We’re currently running six servos all match without issue.

To the topic of defense, to say there’s no defense in FTC is overbroad.  It’s more accurate to say that generally, at the regional level, there isn’t effective defensive play.  You will see it if a team breaks their scoring mechanism or at higher levels like worlds, but even there it’s still usually not a main strategy.

While the rules cited and a few others like  G423 don’t forbid defensive play, it’s still hard to do without drawing fouls.  Our drivers have tried it in practice and found it takes as much or more driver skill to play defense as offense.  That leads to a negative feedback loop.  Our team has limited time for drive practice, so we prioritize scoring rather over defense, which leads to drivers not feeling they have the skills to play defense even in a situation it could make sense.  After a while you have a team culture of “no defense” passed down to younger team members that can reinforce itself across other teams and the rest of the program.

Looping back around to swerve, it’s been quite a while since the GDC put together a game that forced teams into robot on robot contact.  (Ultimate goal would have been a contact game but COVID ruined that).  Until another game like that comes along, there doesn’t appear to be enough other net advantages to swerve to make it worth designing for.

posts.name: guineawheek
posts.cooked:
wgorgen:

It used continuous rotation servos for steering.

Swerves built in this particular era predate the advent of Axon servos that actually provide enough power and durability for swerve pivot to be reasonably reliable, and basically none of them worked well at all outside of reveal videos.

This is incredibly important to know if you do desire to build a swerve in FTC , as otherwise you’re setting yourself up for a lot of busted servos.

Axon servos are pretty much the reason why swerve has become more popular recently even if it is still not a strong competitive advantage. However, you’re still limited by cost, weight, and the sheer size overhead of swerve modules in general.

rwwin:

Our drivers have tried it in practice and found it takes as much or more driver skill to play defense as offense. That leads to a negative feedback loop. Our team has limited time for drive practice, so we prioritize scoring rather over defense, which leads to drivers not feeling they have the skills to play defense even in a situation it could make sense.

It’s also an artifact of 2v2 play; sacrificing 50% of your alliance to play defense is hard to justify in FTC unless you are broken (increasingly uncommon) or otherwise hopelessly outmatched. Vex tends to overemphasize defense resulting in matches that are overly driver centric because everyone has to play defense.

leo-les:

Thats why mecanum is so popular in FTC , and why it’s probably the option you should be going with as a newish FTC team.

The way I like to tell it to FRC people is that running mecanum in FTC is like running swerve in FRC , and that running swerve in FTC is analogous to running diffy swerve in FRC (yeah yeah i know it’s effectively illegal now).

Is diffy swerve theoretically better? Yes. Can you be competitive with it? Yes. Is the cost of getting a good implementation going and its drawbacks (especially relating to small movement) worth it? Not really compared to your COTS coaxial swerve – pretty much the same dynamic with FTC swerves vs mecanum drives.

posts.name: wgorgen
posts.cooked:
guineawheek:

wgorgen:

It used continuous rotation servos for steering.

Swerves built in this particular era predate the advent of Axon servos that actually provide enough power and durability for swerve pivot to be reasonably reliable, and basically none of them worked well at all outside of reveal videos.

I do not remember having a lot of issues with the steering servos. We competed in 5 events that year (2 qualifiers, State Champs, Super-regionals and Worlds) plus lots of driving practice and the servos held up fine. I do not remember what brand they were. The steering was accomplished with a gear drive from the servo to the module. I can’t remember what the gear ratio was, but the steering was fairly slow. So maybe our choice of gear ratio helped the servo longevity.

The only issues we had with the robot that I remember were burning out the shooting motors and chewing up encoder wires in the steering gears. The shooter motors were the Andymark Neverest motors which were pretty much the only legal motors in that era. We had a 3:1 gearbox on those motors with the shooter wheels mounted directly to the gearbox shafts. The students got really good at driving and because of the swerve, we could collect and shoot while driving such that they were were shooting a lot of balls (as you can see in that reveal video). So there was a lot of shock loads on those motors and they were pretty much running continuously. The chewing of the encoder wires was simply poor wire management and the wires were dangling in a location where the gears could grab them.

The swerve was not that interesting to the other teams at the state level. I’m not sure how many of the local teams really knew what swerve was at the time. The judges were pretty impressed as many of them were former FRC students in the era when FRC swerve was mostly home grown designs. Once we got to Super-regionals and Worlds, there was a continuous line of students and adults (mentors and judges) queued up at our pit wanting to talk swerve. We shared our CAD with several other teams at those events and at least one of those teams built an upgraded copy of our design the following year. Our students were pretty happy with their accomplishment. Their goals for the season that year pretty much downplayed winning in favor of doing swerve for the technical challenge. The fact that they were able to also win matches was just a bonus.

posts.name: guineawheek
posts.cooked:
wgorgen:

I can’t remember what the gear ratio was, but the steering was fairly slow. So maybe our choice of gear ratio helped the servo longevity.

This is likely; teams that built swerves in the immediate 2017-2018 season all geared the rotation 1:1 and those implementations would bust up the servos  pretty badly.

wgorgen:

Their goals for the season that year pretty much downplayed winning in favor of doing swerve for the technical challenge. The fact that they were able to also win matches was just a bonus.

Having been a student in this particular era (and remembering the 5795 robot when it was recent), this dynamic fascinates me. Back in those days, building a more technically interesting robot in this sort of fashion was seen very much as trading competitiveness for personal technical novelty, or more cynically, gaming judged awards.

In the ~decade since, however, I feel the general viewpoint of program participants have shifted such that more advanced mechanism designs and fabrication techniques are seen as prerequisites for competitiveness rather than as a tradeoff you do to look cool to yourself and judges.

You still get Fabworks’ed robots that don’t do as well as their appearance would imply, but this tends to be less as a conscious tradeoff to build a unique design but rather due to misplaced strategic aims in the genuine pursuit of greater competitiveness, kind of in the same sense that an FRC team in 2017 might build a beautiful robot that was overly focused on fuel and couldn’t do gears and suffer greatly for it.

To tie this back to the main topic, you even can see this reflected in the way FTC teams talking about swerve nowadays – they are not doing so strictly in the pursuit of doing cool things as they would’ve in 2017 but rather think about it as a genuine strategic choice that could be made.

I don’t know how I feel about this cultural shift overall, personally. On the one hand it’s cool in its own right that the incentives have aligned to push technical creativity to be intertwined with competitive goals, but part of me  feels something got a bit lost in the process. Even though the current FTC game has incredible architectural diversity compared to most seasons, I still miss a little the quirky jankiness of mid-2010s FTC compared to the elegant machines of the mid 2020s.
